article: At the age of seven, I went to see my grandma in Warwick and spent the summer with her. One day I went to a general store with a _ full of what Grandma needed. "Excuse me, I need to _ these," I said . "So ? I'm not your _ ! You should get yourself a basket and start filling," Miss Bee, the owner of the store, said _ without smiling. "If you're _ you'll be home by sunset." Sunset was five hours away. _ , the store was a puzzle, and I wasn't sure if I would make it. I visited Miss Bee several times a week that _ . One afternoon when I watched her adding 35 cents instead of 29 for a can of beans, I _ her immediately. Though being caught overcharging , she didn't seem _ , and she just fixed the price. All summer long I was always tricked by Miss Bee. No sooner had I memorized the soda's location on the shelf than she rearranged the shelves and made me hunt for it all over again. But by summer's end the _ trip that had once taken me an hour was done in 15 minutes. The morning I was to return to Brooklyn, I stepped in to get a bottle of water. "What did you _ this summer?" she said. "That you're so mean!" I whispered. To my _ , Miss Bee laughed. "When you get older, you'll be glad our paths crossed!" Glad I met Miss Bee ? No! Until one day my daughter came to me with homework _ . "It's too hard," she said. "Could you finish it for me?" "If I do it for you, how will you ever learn to do it yourself?" Suddenly, I was _ at that general store where Miss Bee had really taught me something all those years ago.
